characters: AT THE MOUTH OF THE CAVE
A TAROT CARD BEING TURNED OVER
ON THE SIDE OF THE ROAD
EXT -STILL ANOTHER PART OF THE CORNFIELD -NIGHT
A TAROT CARD BEING TURNED OVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s night. Many yesterdays ago. We’re not sure exactly when - but we can tell we’re in the past. A LITTLE BOY, six years old, is sitting next to some bale of hay. An old-fashioned OIL-BURNING LANTERN is next to him, cast flickering shadows on the walls. And now we see where the tune is coming from: The boy staring into a rustic, hand-carved music box. The boy HEARS something. Turning off the music, he scuttles behind some bales of hay to hide. THE BARN DOOR creaks slowly open. Someone --we can’t see who -- enters...wearing LARGE BLAC BOOTS. He’s pushing a big container on wheels. Something’s inside the container -- we can’t see what... because it’s covered by a ratty old TARP. It’s pushed closer...its wheels SQUEAKING. HOLD on the BOY. In his hiding place. Worried. Very worried. The CONTAINER stops -- right in front of the bales of hay Inches from the BOY’s face. And then--- BLACK BOOTS throws back the tarp... revealing a tangled, intriguing CONTRAPTION of pipes and valves and funnels. The BOY -- peers through the bales of hay, not sure what the man doing. But whatever it is....it’s horrific. Something red..and sticky gushes through the valves and pipes. .goi into the funnel, sticking into the plastic sac. The boy pulls back in fright --snapping a piece off the music box...causing it to PLAY again. The boy is terrified. BLACK BOOTS ....turns toward the source of the music. A look of sheer horror in the boy’s eyes. The boy’s trembling hands scramble to cover the music box To stop it. To quiet it somehow.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK BOOTS
dialogues.text: ---advances. Closer, closer -- The boy tries to crawl away -deserting the music box still playing. A gloved HAND reaches out, grabbing his ankle. The boy struggles. A LANTERN falls, immediately setting fire to the surround straw. A horrible scream of rage -- as the black boots catch fir The man writhes. Screaming. A human fireball. The fire spreads everywhere. The boy, terrified, tries to scramble out through a loose plank in the barn wall... The fire rages on. The screaming continues.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: It’s dark, deserted, lonely. The harvest moon is shining overhead. And then -- The approaching HEADLIGHTS of a soft-top convertible, whipping up dust as it zooms along. Loud ROCK MUSIC blari  from within.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A MASK similar to the one used in "SCREAM". It’ on the face of the DRIVER of the car. He’s also wearing a

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: HOOD and CAPE. He turns to look at the PRETTY YOUNG WOMAN in the passeng seat. She’s KAREN, about 18, fresh out of high school. She’s wearing a skimpy BIKINI with a leopard-skin pattern, a necklace of ANIMAL CLAWS, and not much else. She rubs her goose-pimply arms --

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Jeez, close that window, Ray! I’m freezing in here. --And take off that stupid mask. He whips off his mask, and tucks it underneath his cape. Meet RAY, about 20, athletic, a bit of a prankster. He leers at Karen --

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I can’t help it, babe. You bring out the monster in me. Ray puts a hand on her exposed thigh. Karen removes it.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Not while you’re driving. Karen pops open a beer.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Throw me one.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Not while you’re driving. As Karen chugs her beer, Ray can’t help glancing at her cleavage. KAREN (CONT’D) --And keep your eyes on the road.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I’m admiring your costume. What "movie" are you going as again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheena, Queen of the Jungle. Off Ray’s blank stare --

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Never heard of it.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I’m not surprised. It’s got a body count of zero. And no one goes around ina stupid mask, hacking innocent people to death.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: (re: the mask) You don’t like my costume? Cool. I’11 go with plan B. Which one you like better? With one hand on the wheel, Ray holds up two other masks The white SHAPE face from the "Halloween" series...and a HOCKEY MASK from "Friday the 13th". Karen rolls her eyes. RAY (CONT’D) Hey...wanna see something really scary? Ray reaches down under the seat, taking his eyes off the road. Before he can get any further, KAREN’S eyes widen in terror--

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Watch out!!! As she GRABS the steering wheel --

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A COW, standing dumbly in the middle of the road. The car swerves wildly, knocking over a signpost --

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: ---as it careens off to the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rows and rows of CORN smashing against the glass. Finally, the car comes to rest in the middle of the FIELD Clouds of dust reflected in the headlight beams. The HORN  blares.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT
dialogues.text: Ray turns to check Karen--she’s unconscious, head back on the seat.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Karen...? Oh, geez! Karen....? He quickly feels her pulse. Then he puts his hand over her heart, trying to find a heartbeat. He pauses for a moment. He can’t help himself -- his hand moves slo-o0-o-o-wly upwards, towards her breasts. Suddenly, KAREN’s eyes pop open -- and she grabs his hand and pushes it away. She’s been playing possum.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Is that all you ever think of? Suppose I was really hurt!

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Dammit, Karen--- I was just...looking for your pulse.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: --By way of my breasts? She huffs.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Sit tight.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CAR HOOD
dialogues.text: ---being opened by RAY. There’s a little steam coming out and the engine’s hot.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: (burns himself) Ow!

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Nothing. I’1l have us back on the road in no time. RAY looks down and sees the smashed wooden SIGN, stuck i the RADIATOR GRILLE. He eases it out -- The sign reads..."No trespassing -- J. Macdonald." RAY (CONT’D) (realizes) Hey -- Macdonald’s farm!

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Ray---I’d like to get to the club sometime before dawn. Karen holds a "flyer" for a music club.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Be right back. Gotta irrigate the corn. We STAY WITH RAY-as he walks deeper into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lit by the moon and shafts of the car headlights, it’s eerie, quiet...scary.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: (singing to himself) --Old Macdonald had a farm, e-i-e-io...and on that farm, he ---almost ran over a cow ---e-i, e-i, ohhhhh-- Looking for a place to pee, Ray turns a corner surrounded by a wall of corn. He unzips his fly, and swaying, relieves himself in a wid arc. For the first time, he casually turns to his left to see-

dialogues.speaker: A SCARY FIGURE
dialogues.text: silhouetted against the moonlight, standing next to him--

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: (startled) --Jesus!!! --But it’s only a harmless SCARECROW, arms outstretched on a pole. Ray suddenly looks down, realizes he’s pissing on himself and his cape.  RAY (CONT’D) Dammit!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAREN is still sitting in the car, bopping to music on the CD player. She preens herself, tuck her breasts into her leopard costume, awaiting Ray’s return.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: RAY appraises the SCARECROW --tentatively pokes him. It’s made of straw.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Fuckin’ scarecrow. He takes a piece of straw, puts it in his mouth. He turns around, going back to the car, moving past the corn field Suddenly, RAY halts -- something pulls him backwards! We HEAR a ripping sound. Ray slowly turns around to see -- HIS CAPE -- caught on a piece of WIRE. He shudders, pulls it off. Ray takes another step forward. --Did he just hear something in the cornfield with him -- or was it his imagination?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: KAREN’s a little anxious. Ray should have been back by no She leans out the window, trying to look past the open ca HOOD.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (calls out) How many beers did you have, Ray?! Beat. No answer. KAREN (CONT’D) (calls out) Raymond. .?!! No answer. Karen turns the music off. She peers out the window, the open hood obscuring her view. Still no sign of Ray. FLAP FLAP FLAP -- several nightjar BIRDS flutter out of t  cornfield, unsettling her. KAREN (CONT’D) weenie eens Ray?? Still no sign of Ray. Karen’s starting to get very worrie Something’s not right. And then-- A FIGURE wearing the cape and Scream Mask POPS UP next to her - scaring the shit out of her. Karen freaks. KAREN (CONT’D) Geez! ---That wasn’t funny! The MASKED FIGURE with the cape just stands outside the car, looking at her. KAREN (CONT’D) Okay, Ray. I’m freezing. Get in the car. The MASKED FIGURE stands there, unmoving, by her open window. Just staring. A feeling of unease washes over Karen. Maybe this figure....... isn’t Ray at all. KAREN (CONT’D) »Ray...? And then, the MASKED FIGURE raises his arm -- and we see a shiny, long-bladed KNIFE clenched in his fist. The FIGURE brings the BLADE down, PLUNGING it through the open window--and into Karen’s chest! Karen SCREAMS. She looks down at the blade. And the blood on her bare skin. Beat. KAREN (CONT’D) --Owwww! =That hurt!!! The Masked Figure "pulls out" the retractable KNIFE blade and takes off his mask. It is indeed...Ray. Always the joker. He squeezes the knife handle by way of demonstration...a little fake "blood" comes out of the blade.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Fake blood. Cool, huh? Karen is like, totally unamused. She wipes herself off, glaring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on, Karen! RAY starts stabbing himself in the chest to demonstrate-- RAY (CONT’D) It’s a retractable blade! You couldn’t cut yourself if you wanted to! Look! ---Suddenly another blade protrudes from Ray’s chest. A REAL one. A long-handled farm SCYTHE has swung around -- hitting him in the back, the cold blade RIPPING through him. A thin stream of blood drips from his surprised lips. This definitely ain’t a trick. Karen SCREAMS. And screams some more. In the darkness, we can’t see who’s wielding the scythe. The BLADE is pulled out, Ray slumps to the ground, dead. ON TwO BOOTS --the killer’s boots. Black farm boots. The blade of the SCYTHE dangles down next to them. The boots begin walking around to the other side of the car.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CAR
dialogues.text: KAREN freaks, realizing she’s next. She quickly LOCKS the car doors. Silence. The KILLER seems to have vanished. But her WINDOW’S still half-open! Karen reaches out for the electric window button. She pushes it. The window closes..... closes...closes..... WHOOSH! The blade of the SCYTHE swings in at the last second, getting caught between the glass and the frame, inches from Karen’s face. As the unseen KILLER pulls out the scythe and the window automatically closes---KAREN sees her chance--  10. She CLIMBS into the driver’s seat, hitting the RADIO -- the MUSIC comes back on, LOUD. Karen turns the ignition key. The ENGINE turns over immediately. She just might escape--

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TIRES
dialogues.text: They SPIN in the ditch trying to get traction. And then---the FRONT TIRES grab the dirt! Karen’s about to free the car, when---- WHOOSH! The BLADE of the scythe plunges into the rubber deflating the front tire with a rush of air. KAREN’s POV - THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD Obscured by the raised hood, she sees THE SCYTHE being raised up -- and coming down -- straight into the engine. There’s some SPARKS-- and a SNAP OF WIRES being severed. And the engine dies. Ditto the music. Silence, except for Karen’s hyperventilation. And_ then------ a final realization comes over Karen. She ...looks up. Remembering....she’s in a convertible -- and the top is made of CANVAS. And then-- --The SCYTHE ..... sweeps down in a deadly arc, tearing through the TOP of the car, almost slicing her ear off. A GASH opens on her bare arm. Karen SCREAMS. She KICKS open the CAR DOOR---and stumbles into--

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: KAREN runs ...for her life. And runs some more. And someone--or something’s-- following her.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Out of breath, Karen sees a light up ahead. AN OLD FARMHOUSE. People. A telephone. Safety.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: She frantically bangs on the door, trying to force it ope  11.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (hysterical) Please! I need...help! No answer. No one’s home. Hurt and bleeding, Karen turns to her right -- and sees - An Old BARN. A place to hide.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: With as much stealth as she can, Karen pushes open the old, creaky barn door. She leaves a BLOODY HANDPRINT on the door--

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: It’s deathly quiet. Moonlight shining on bales of hay, glinting on farm implements. Silence. Then -- from outside, a cow MOOS -- Then a loud CHUFFING sound. A HORSE. And then -- a few CHICKENS begin to CLUCK.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Shhh. ..SHHHH -- The animals seems to be jittery, nervous. The HORSE whinnies loudly. The COW moos again. KAREN puts her hands to her ears, trying to block out the unholy chorus -- She backs away -- A FIGURE is behind her. She backs into it and swings around to see-- A SCARECROW. Burlap skin, jagged, stitched mouth. Cold eyes. Cold, and... alive. SCARECROW’S POV: looking through the burlap at Karen. The SCARECROW raises a gleaming SCYTHE high in the air. It swings down --  12. Karen screams. For the very last time.

dialogues.speaker: A GUY SCREAMING
dialogues.text: ---into a microphone. We PULL BACK, revealing we’re at a-

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The kind of smoky dive. Some of the audience members are wearing Halloween masks and/or costumes. On stage, several beats away from the big time, a hungry, hard-working rock band. Ladies and gentlemen, meet Dead Quiet: On guitar and lead vocals...JOSEPH "MAC" MACDONALD, 24. Charismatic, driven. With a dark side. The leader. On bass guitar...SUZIE, 24. Hot, punky. A sex-bomb, primed to detonate at any moment.. On keyboards...KEITH, 25. Black, street-wise. Attitude. On drums & percussion...IAN, 30. Party animal. At the moment, Mac is singing his heart out, sharing the mike with SUZIE, drawing on her sexual energy. Meanwhile, Keith keeps glancing over at the side of the STAGE, as if waiting for someone to appear. Looks as if there’s a band member missing. Keith shouts over to Mac.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Where is he? Mac steps back and shouts over the music to CARL (20), the band’s all-round gopher and roadie--

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Carl! Where’s Rod? Carl doesn’t hear. He’s too busy gazing at the flip-scree monitor of a small HAND-HELD DIGITAL VIDEO CAMERA. He’s close up on Suzie. Mac, shouting, his voice just about drowned out by the music - MAC (CONT’D) Carl! Carl snaps to attention. Sees the empty mike stand.  13. As the band continues playing, we FOLLOW CARL, still arme with his CAMCORDER, into --

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Carl stops in front of a closed DOOR. He knocks tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Uh... .Hello?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE FROM INSIDE
dialogues.text: Fuck off! CARL instantly recognizes the voice. He hesitates, and then knocks again --

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Rod? You’re missing your cue! MAN’S VOICE No man! I’m right on it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON ROD RYDER, 26, the band’s cocksure, devil-may-ca lead guitarist. Talented. And doesn’t care who knows it. At the moment, he’s slouching in a chair with his shirt unbuttoned. CANDY, a foxy babe with a passion for new age philosophy and musicians -- is sitting on his lap, her tongue down his throat.

dialogues.speaker: INT BACKSTAGE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: CARL can hear MOANING coming from inside. He grins. Stealthily, he stands on tiptoe and reaches out as high he can, aiming the camcorder through the clear pane of GLASS at the top of the door. He looks up at the angled flip-screen, hoping to catch a glimpse of the action. But all he sees is a flashing "BATTERY" icon on the screen. Then nothing. Damn!

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Rod!

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: He’s coming! CARL sighs, pointing the rapidly-dying camcorder at himself --  14.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Note to self: remember to recharge battery.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The BAND continues to play, doing the best they can. An unimpressed audience member hurls a BEER-BOTTLE at the stage. It just misses Keith’s head. Keith is furious, ready to explode. He gets up from his seat, fists clenched around his drumsticks. Mac gives him a look - "stay cool." He backs down.

dialogues.speaker: INT BACKSTAGE ROOM
dialogues.text: ROD and CANDY have finished. Candy has progressed from ha undressed, to half-dressed. Rod’s in no real hurry to get on stage. He checks his hair in the mirror, and deftly buttons up his shirt. Then he looks around --

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: Where’s my axe? Candy straps his Fender Stratocaster guitar around his ne She gazes adoringly at him --

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: Kill ‘em, baby.

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: They’re as good as dead.

dialogues.speaker: INT MUSIC CLUB
dialogues.text: As Mac and the band head for the SONG’S crescendo, ROD walks a tad unsteadily on stage. Perfect timing. He announces h presence with a blistering guitar break. The AUDIENCE perk up a little. Some cheers, some whistles The band members glare at Rod.  15.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: It’s after the set. The door bursts open -- the band are tired and sweaty.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Motherfucking soundman! I couldn’t hear myself sing!

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: (teasing) I could. You sucked.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Hey. Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Where’s Jack? Anybody seen Jack? CARL is there too, eye glued to his CAMCORDER, panning across the band-members. Suzie whips off her sweaty top. Carl’s eyes widen as he zooms in on her naked breasts. She catches sight of CARL, and hurls her top at him --

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Pervert! Carl ducks. Suzie puts on a fresh top -- SUZIE (CONT’D) Jesus. What a bunch of useless zombies.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Who? Us?!

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: (grinning) The audience!

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: (distracted) Jack! There you are, buddy! We see IAN grabbing a half-full bottle of liquor from a mess of items on a table. JACK DANIELS. He swigs. Keith holds out his hand for some.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (enthusiastic) My man!  16. Ian finishes the whiskey, hands the empty bottle to Keith KEITH (CONT’D) (dryly) My man. ROD strides in. CANDY, his groupie, is hanging onto his arm. Suzie glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: Hey, guys. Good gig. SUZIE walks over to Rod face to face --

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Great work, Rod. But next time, it would be nice ....if you could JOIN US

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: I was getting ‘warmed’ up. Rod smiles slyly at Candy. SUZIE’S had enough.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Who do you think we are, dude? Your back up band                        ! CANDY jumps in, defiantly to Suzie --

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: Get off his case sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: (to Candy) Where’d you come from? Groupies R Us?

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Fuck me? Fuck YOU!! Rod grins, enjoying the attention, when--- SKREEEEEEEEECH!!! --- The sound of GUITAR FEEDBACK, like nails on a blackboard. MAC, electric GUITAR in hand. The guitar is plugged into small but powerful practice amp. He’s certainly got their attention.  17.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Time for a little.. "feedback" guys. That guy from Hectic Records --

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: --picked tonight to come by and watch our set.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Relax. He liked what he saw. Well, some of it. Enough to give us a showcase audition. One week from today.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Which means we’ve got ONE week to start acting like a professional band.

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: Hey. Anyone here need lessons, just talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’1l teach you a lesson -- Suzie grabs Rod by the shirt and crotch and shoves him against the wall. CANDY tries to grab SUZIE by the hair. SUZIE holds her away at arms length, whilst pinning ROD to the wall. It’s an action Lara Croft would be proud of. SUZIE’S not a girl to mess with. Rod’s enjoying this. CARL begins shooting away on his camcorder. Mac tries to stop the ruckus.

dialogues.speaker: OK. OK
dialogues.text: CANDY is furious at ROD’S laid back attitude.

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: Bitch.  18.

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: It’s OK baby. And then----they all become aware of a new presence. A STRANGER is standing in the doorway. Unshaven, dressed in farm clothes and black boots. Out of place in the city

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (aside; to Mac) ...That’s not.. the record guy, is it? Mac shakes his head "no", not taking his eyes off the stranger. Then- -

dialogues.speaker: STRANGER
dialogues.text: Joseph Macdonald? Mac looks him in the eye-- STRANGER (CONT’D) Your aunt Edith’s dead. Beat. A slight reaction from Mac. The stranger fumbles in his pocket, pulling out a letter. He offers it to Mac. STRANGER (CONT’D) It’s from your father. Mac hesitates. Then he takes the letter, glances at it...then crumples it. The Stranger smiles slightly,almost as if he expected it. And then-- STRANGER (CONT’D) He also asked me..to give you this. The Stranger puts something else in Mac’s hand. It’s a small HAND-CARVED WOODEN FIGURE of a Scarecrow... damaged at the base. Old...worn. Mac seems entranced by it. STRANGER (CONT’D) Funeral’s tomorrow afternoon. At the farm. As the Stranger smiles slightly, exits just as quickly as he appeared. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Farm? ..What farm?

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: An old, beat-up SCHOOL BUS, with the name "Dead Quiet" emblazoned across it, traveling down a dusty road. Equipm and luggage fastened on top. Pinioned to the back of the bus, a rough-and-ready-looking OFF-ROAD MOTORBIKE.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: CARL is driving, looking a little lost as he veers his wa over the rough and tumble country road. He holds the letter with directions to the farm Mac ripped up, now tap together. Mac is sitting alone. Pensive. He holds the small wooden figure. ROD & CANDY, who’s come along for the ride -- sit next to Keith and Ian. Candy has her eyes closed, meditating. They’re playing some kind of "on the road" game --

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Okay. My main man. Marvin Gaye.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Easy. Gunshot. Patricide. Next.

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: Curt Cobain.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Shotgun. Suicide. Next?

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Wait a second. Did you say "patricide?"

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Marvin’s old man gunned him down.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: That’s not patricide. Patricide is when you gun down your old man.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: All right. "Fratricide". Minor technical detail.  They all stare

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Wrong. Fratricide is when you gun down your brother. You’re out. My turn.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Fine. Be that way. Jim Morison.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Died in the bathtub...if, in fact, he’s really dead. Next.

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: Mama Cass.

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: Who’s Mama Cass? at her.

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: One of the Mamas from the Mamas and the Papas. Candy looks blank. Suzie looks at

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Asphyxiation. Choked to death on a hamsandwich. Next.

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: (triumphant; makes quiz show buzzer sound) Buzzzzzzzzzz. Sorry, wrong answer !

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Chicken sandwich?

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: (loudly) Bzzzzzzzzzt!

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Fuck you! Who cares what sandwich the bitch was eating? Mac, sitting a few rows behind them. turns to the others--

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Hey. Could you be a little more insensitive? We’re on our way to a funeral for Crissake. She 20.  21.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yeah. Our own. I don’t see why we got to go along for the ride.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Come on, dude. A day ona farm isn’t going to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: .. Heart attack. Everyone looks at him. MAC (CONT’D) Mama Cass died of a heart attack. The ham sandwich is just an urban legend.

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: (to Rod) Who’s the Mamas and the Papas?

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The BUS cruises along, getting deeper into farmland territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie sits down next to Mac.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: You never told us you grew up on a farm.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Nothing to tell. Suzie stares at him, not giving up. MAC (CONT’D) ..My parents separated when I was just a kid. I chose my mother. My father chose the farm. Haven’t been back since. I’ve maybe talked to him twice in twelve years. Off Suzie’s look-- MAC (CONT’D) My father and I don’t exactly see eye to eye.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name something.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Then why go back now?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Still trying to figure it out myself. 22. Beat. Mac glances down at the wooden figure in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ON IAN AND KEITH
dialogues.text: Ian accidentally steps on Keith’s sneakers.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: New "shoes," Keith? Keith proudly lifts up his feet, revealing of -

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Nike specials. Two hundred bucks.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Two hundred bucks?? Are you crazy? a brand new pair Keith meticulously begins wiping them off with newspaper

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Hey. Never criticize a man ‘till you’ve walked a mile in his shoes. Then you can criticize...’cause you’1l1 be a mile away...and you’11l have his shoes. They laugh-- KEITH (CONT’D) Speaking of which--yo, CARL! Are we THERE yet?!

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (driving; to himself) Like I know. Hey, Mac! Any of this look familiar??

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Try taking a left after the next cow pasture.  23.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (mutters, to Ian) Yeah. That sounds good. "Hang a left at the first cow patty, then make a right when you see porky pig". Mac grins slightly, looks out the window, to see--

dialogues.speaker: EXT -SIDE OF THE ROAD
dialogues.text: An OLD WOMAN, standing at a rundown STALL, outside a mode FARM HOUSE. Some corn dolls, pumpkins, and dry husks of maize are hanging up on display. Next to her stands a short farmhand, her brother. MAC catches her gaze. There’s something intense and very unsettling about the w her eyes lock on to his.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: WIDE on a large FIELD as the bus passes by. A BURNING stack of diseased crops. Smoke and flames crackling, rising to the sky. The bus continues, past-- A long shot of a SCARECROW, distant and alone in a field. And then -- the BUS rises over a small hill....revealing old wooden sign we’ve seen before -- "No Trespassing - J. Macdonald".

dialogues.speaker: ON MAC.
dialogues.text: ...He’s finally come "home".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting closer, the BUS passes a scraggly menagerie of FARMYARD ANIMALS. Cows, horses, goats, chickens. Finally, it pulls up to a cluster of SHEDS and COOPS and farm BUILDINGS. Mac’s eye finally settles on -- THE OLD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There’s something strangely compelling about it...something that seems to strike a chord deep inside his memory. This is MACDONALD’S FARM. Maybe this was a prosperous farm once. But once was a long time ago. The BUS pulls up and stops in the yard between the farmhouse and barn. The DOORS whoosh open--

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: KEITH and IAN exchange a somewhat nervous glance as they gaze out the window. As the band get their things, moving to get off the bus, KEITH pulls down a duffle bag and draws out a pearl hande 38. SPECIAL. Suzie notices the gun.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: You know what they say about men who need big guns...

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Hey. Some Klu Klux Klan homeboy gets in my face, he gonna have a few extra holes in his bedsheet.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: (teasing) Down boy.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Who you callin’ "boy?" Smirking, Keith moves down the aisle. As Suzie and Candy wait to exit the bus, they shoot daggers at each other.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Tramp. Rod grins, enjoying himself.  25.

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: After you....ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band members file out of the bus. They glance around the dilapidated farm. Candy suddenly seems concerned --

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: Rod. Check out my chakras. Rod, puzzled, stares at her body. Candy fingers the crystals around her neck. CANDY (CONT’D) They’ve gone darker. Bad vibes. Suzie, nearby rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: ...shoots the area with his CAMCORDER.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Note to self: Farming not a career option. Beat. Carl sneezes. The others look at him. CARL (CONT’D) ..Hay fever.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Man, you came to the wronnng place.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Be right back. Try to stay out of trouble. Mac moves off -- as Keith looks around.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yeah. Maybe I can pick a little cotton for da masta.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: You got something against farm people, Keith?  26.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Not at all. They lynched my ancestors, they smell like manure, they have sex with their relatives... and they all have two first names: "Bobby - Joe"- -

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: (joining in, smiling) "Peggy-Sue"---

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: ---"Billy-Jean"-- Mac walks up to the barn. He seems strangely hesitant. Slowly, he reaches out his hand. Then he freezes -- As he notices a BLOODY HANDPRINT on the door. We recognize it as the handprint of the girl who was murdered last night. Just then, the BARN DOOR creaks open, revealing... THE STRANGER that everyone recognizes as the one who delivered the note backstage. Only now he’s wearing a blood stained apron, black farm boots and in his left hand....a KNIFE...dripping with blood. The Stranger holds up the knife--grins--

dialogues.speaker: STRANGER
dialogues.text: Takes ‘em a full thirty seconds to realize they ain’t got a head. Everyone stares--

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: Chickens! Glad you could make it. --Name’s Billy Bob. Keith gives an "I told you so" look. Mac shakes hands --then looks at his palm. There’s CHICKE BLOOD all over his hand. Billy Bob grins. He wipes the excess blood on his apron.  27. BILLY BOB (CONT’D) Your pa’s waiting for you up at the house.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: How’d he know I’d come? Billy Bob just grins enigmatically. As Mac heads toward the FARM HOUSE --

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: Sorry ‘bout your aunt. Billy Bob picks a chicken up by its feet, getting the knife ready, about to go back into the barn--

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Great. Billy Bob hears and turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: I’d watch your step if I were you, son.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Why’s that?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: You’re standing in horseshit. Keith looks down. Yep -- he’s standing in horseshit, alright.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Damn! These are one hundred dollar Nikes!

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I thought you said two hundred. Billy Bob grins. Spits a globule of black tobacco right next to Keith’s shoes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT -FARM HOUSE, (FRONT ENTRANCE)
dialogues.text: MAC stops, eyeing the house. It sighs and creaks with a life of its own. As he opens the screen door to go inside

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Mac glances around. Shades pulled down, dark and musty furniture. Stuffed animal heads on the walls. A spiderweb in the corner.  28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rod is picking at his guitar as Candy looks on admiringly SUZIE is unpacking some bags off the bus rack, unaware that CARL is shooting her ass with his CAMCORDER. IAN snaps off his cellphone, pissed.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Perfect. No signal. IAN peers over Carl’s shoulder, sees Suzie’s ass on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That got a zoom lense?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Brace yourself. As he "zooms" in on Suzie’s buns--

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Will you guys quit jerking off and give me a hand here! As they grin and help her unload the bus, Ian unloads a b full of Jack Daniels bottles---

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Hiya Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac is wandering around the room, uneasy. Suddenly, he hears a flapping noise. It seems to be coming from behind a closed door.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: ...Jeremiah? Mac pushes open the door to--

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: As he walks into the dark, smaller room, he looks to his right to see-- A SHUTTER...flapping slightly from the wind. That’s all. Mac sighs. He turns to his left -- and --  29.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Daaa! He almost falls over his AUNT. Dead, laid out "in state" on a long, OAK TABLE, candles all around her.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.C)
dialogues.text: Hold it right there. Turn around slowly. MAC slowly turns to see--- -- his father, JEREMIAH MACDONALD, late sixties, weathere but strong, a man who’s spent his life working hard on a farm. He’s wearing work clothes - overalls, and yes, black farm boots. With a crazed look in his eye, he’s pointing a shotgun straight at Mac.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? Shoot me?

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Depends. You got some nerve intruding on a man’s grief. I bet I could pull this trigger right now and call it justifiable homicide. Now: who are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: You know who I am. You invited me. CLICK CLACK! Jeremiah pumps the shotgun, chambering a round. Mac’s unsettled. Perhaps Jeremiah’s gone over the deep end--

dialogues.speaker: MAC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m your son. And Laureen’s son.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Ain’t nobody mentioned that name on this farm for 14 years. My boy was taken from me... far as I’m concerned, he’s dead. Now, I ain’t gonna ask you again. -- Who are you?!

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Joseph Macdonald... Your son.  30.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Joseph Macdonald. Damn right, boy. And don’t you forget it. Jeremiah lowers the shotgun, grins-- JEREMIAH (CONT’D) I’m just yankin’ your chain! It seems Jeremiah has an offbeat sense of humor. JEREMIAH (CONT’D) Come here...I ain’t gonna bite. MAC approaches cautiously. Jeremiah grabs Mac, hugging him- - Mac’s pretty awkward, but he puts up with this. JEREMIAH (CONT’D) Look at you! You’re a dead ringer for your grandpa, God rest his soul. If he could only see you now. Mac looks at Edith. A wave of remorse washes over him.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I came back for the funeral. That’s all.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Broke her heart you never visited. ..But I always said you’d come back. Jeremiah reaches down, tenderly strokes his sister’s hair

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I’1l be gone again tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: ..Guess it was her time to go. You can’t argue...when the good Lord calls you home. There’s an awkward beat --

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: How...was she "called?"

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Aunt Edith. How did she...die?  31. Jeremiah puts a PIPE in his mouth, lights it.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: "Natural causes."

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: We’re in a small family graveyard on a HILL by the farmhouse, where Macdonalds have been buried for centurie A PREACHER stands nearby, conducting the service for Edith. He stands between Billy Bob and Jeremiah. Two three LOCALS from the village have also come to pay their respects. A few feet away are the rest of the band, standing awkwardly. They’d rather be somewhere else. Mac stands beside Suzie. She gently squeezes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: ..and we ask you to bestow your blessing on this worthless band of sinners. And so....ashes to ashes...dust to dust..

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (making a rhyme sotto voce) --Let’s hurry up and get back on the bus.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: We are here to honor the memory of Edith Macdonald...and deliver her to her eternal rest. ON JEREMIAH. Head bowed, reverent, dressed in a sombre black suit. MAC watches him. CARL surreptitiously opens the flip-screen of his camcorder to shoot the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (quietly, to Ian) Shit, when I die, hope there’s a bigger turn-out.  32.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: To everything there is a season, a time to be born - a time to die. A time to kill...and a time to heal... As the Preacher talks, Mac suddenly sees-- ---a WOMAN, dressed in black, with a veil over her face. Odd. He didn’t notice her before. The Woman moves closer to Mac....closer...she removes the veil. A mixture of terror and fury-- PREACHER (CONT’D) --a time to keep silent, and a time to speak-- The woman looks Mac directly in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: The devil has returned. Mac recognizes the Old Woman (JESSE) from the lonely farm stall on the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I...pardon...?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You look just like him. Like Jethro.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: (hard; to the woman) You’re not welcome here, Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I came to pay my respects. (beat) And to warn you.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: I want you off my land. -- Keep reading, Reverend.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: (clears his throat; trying to continue) Er...a time to love...a time to ..hate--  33.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: (to Jeremiah) It’s started again, hasn’t it? The harvest of blood. I know. I can feel it. Your father’s legacy of evil--

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: --My daddy’s dead. You and the others saw to that.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. And burning in hell! And you’re going to join him--wait and see!

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: Uh, a time to embrace. .and a time to refrain from embracing....

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Get out of here. Or so help me-- Something snaps in Jeremiah’s head. He picks up a shovel, raising it as a weapon--

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: A time to--holy shit!! Jeremiah--NO!! Mac grabs Jeremiah, struggling to keep the shovel away from Jesse’s head. Candy screams. CARL seizes the moment, taping the action with his camcorder. JESSE stands her ground. Looks coldly at Mac.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (to Mac) The sins of the fathers shall be visited upon their children’s children. And the sword shall be made drunk with their blood. She spits on the ground, walking away. Mac releases his hold on Jeremiah.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (low) Damn. White folks usually chill at funerals.  34.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: (quickly) Uh, I commit Edith Macdonald to the blessed soil of the land she knew and cherished. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: OTHERS
dialogues.text: Amen. The PREACHER nods to Billy Bob, who gently takes the shovel from Mac. He spits on his palms, rubs them togethe As the first pile of dirt hits the coffin--

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The funeral’s over. As the others walk down the hill, Jeremiah is shaking hands with the PREACHER --

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Sorry about the shovel, Eugene. Guess I got a little carried away.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: The lord forgives your sins Jeremiah. Can’t say the same about the law. As he says this, the Preacher gets in his car---which we now see is a SHERIFF’S SQUAD CAR. He yanks off his clerical collar, as if it’s been strangling him, puts dow his bible. He reaches on the seat and just as swiftly puts a SHERIFF’S HAT on his head. He eyes the other band members PREACHER (CONT’D) Keep an eye on your guests. We don’t want no pot smoking musicians spoiling things around here.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. S’all under control. Workin’ on any big cases?

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: Nah. Things are dead quiet. As the sheriff’s car pulls out, Jeremiah watches -- his eyes are now on the BARN some distance away. MAC’s there, pushing open the barn door. Jeremiah smiles slightly.  35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BARN DOOR CREAKS open. Exploring, MAC enters the barn by himself. It’s a big, ru down structure that has seen better harvests. Hanging up is an impressive array of scythes, axes, hoes, and sickles. Simple, functional FARM IMPLEMENTS - but the light gives their blades a sudden edge of menace. The afternoon sunlight filters through the wooden slats, hitting a pile of straw, dust rising up from it. Then..... MAC notices something -- SOMEBODY’S LEGS. -- clad in dirty jeans, old shoes...stretched out and partly hidden behind a barn STALL. Someone’s sitting there, quietly biding their time. MAC moves closer. And closer. Until he sees -- A raggedy old SCARECROW, propped up against the stall. Harmless. Mac bends over to check it out ... unaware that there’s somebody else in the barn with him.

dialogues.speaker: A SCYTHE
dialogues.text: --hanging on the wall is removed from its place.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: --is still looking at the old scarecrow, when-- WHOOSH! -- The deadly blade comes sweeping down, slicing the air near him. Mac spins around to see-- IAN, scythe in hand, stoned, doing "Kung Fu" moves.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Hey dude -- don’t fear the reaper! Beat. Mac stares, the color drained from his face. IAN (CONT’D) So. When’s dinner?  36.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. -CORNFIELD -MAGIC HOUR
dialogues.text: The Scarecrow, hanging alone in the field. The sun is sinking.

dialogues.speaker: INT -BATHROOM -NIGHT
dialogues.text: CANDY’s going to take a shower. She looks around the bathroom. Something creepy about it. She takes off her robe, turns on the shower. Gets under the water. It feels good.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DOORKNOB
dialogues.text: It starts to turn. Slowly at first. Then the knob TWISTS back and forth, violently.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALL WAY -SAME TIME
dialogues.text: It’s Suzie twisting the knob. It’s locked. Suzie wears nothing but a towel, impatient to shower. She bangs on the door.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Hey! Don’t use all the hot water!

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: Keep your shirt on! I’m almost done!

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Bitch.

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: Bitch.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALL WAY
dialogues.text: Suddenly, from behind Suzie, two HANDS grab her. Suzie spins around. It’s MAC. He moves in closer, holding her--  37.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Ten thirty. My room. Clothing optional. Suzie smiles meaningfully.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: What about Jeremiah?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Nah. Just you. As they kiss--- Suddenly, we hear a terrible SCREAM from inside the bathroom and-- Mac twists the door handle, still locked and-- it’s an old door, so he easily forces it open and they rush in to the bathroom, and--

dialogues.speaker: INT BATHROOM-CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: --Mac throws aside the shower curtain, and-- --Candy’s standing there, naked, terrified. Shaking, she points--

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: Look. There’s a medium-sized SPIDER high up on the wall. Mac and Suzie stand there, incredulous. Rod, Ian and Carl rush into the bathroom--

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: What is it?!!

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: (pissed) Spider. Beat. As all the men stare--

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (enjoying the view) I’1l get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON A PLATE OF WHOLE COOKED CHICKENS and MEAT...the result of Billy Bob’s handiwork. JEREMIAH and Billy Bob are eating heartily without a care in the world.  38. Mac and the others watch them. There’s a bottle of MOONSHINE. Ian takes a SIP-- -- and chokes--

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Best corn liquor in the county. Make it myself. Edith used to say: the two hardest things to swallow...are pride and moonshine.

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: I can think of a third. Carl and Billy Bob chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: (takes another sip) How’d...you...make it, exactly? Jeremiah leans closer, looks Ian straight in the eye --

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Well, I could tell you...but then, I’d have to cut your throat and gut you like a pig. Silence. Jeremiah laughs. The others look at each other, smiling tentatively-- JEREMIAH (CONT’D) Just yanking your chain! Old family secret. He looks across at Mac -- JEREMIAH (CONT’D) Some things are better left that way. Right, son? Mac ignores this. There’s an awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Uh...thanks for dinner. It was delicious. Suzie’s anxious to leave the table, meet up with Mac. Jeremiah looks wistful.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Chicken. Used to be Edith’s favorite.  39. Beat. Jeremiah chokes up, suddenly remorseful.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: (raises his glass) To...Edith. May she rest in peace.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: To...Edith. Everyone... drinks. Suzie wants to leave.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Well-- Jeremiah raises his glass again --

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: --and..... to my...son. Everyone settles back in again-- JEREMIAH (CONT’D) ...The last of the Macdonalds. wWho’sfinally been called back home. Jeremiah and Mac lock eyes. JEREMIAH (CONT’D) Even if it is... for one day. Everyone drinks. But it’s not over yet. JEREMIAH (CONT’D) And to....

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: The farm? Suzie rolls her eyes, glares at Candy. Candy smirks.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: (raises his glass) Good idea, little lady. "The farm."

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: To "Old Macdonald’s farm" --

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: "E-I, E-I, Oh --"

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: The GLASS suddenly SHATTERS in Jeremiah’s hand. Rivulets of blood on his fingers. At first, he doesn’t  40. notice.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Your hand is bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: ...Excuse me. Jeremiah gets up, holding his hand, goes into the kitchen

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Damn. Whassup with that? No one speaks at first.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: You just reminded him...of Jethro.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Who's Jethro? No one answers. SUZIE (CONT’D) Who's Jethro?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: Jethro Macdonald.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: ...My grandfather. Everyone turns toward Mac. When he doesn’t continue---

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: "Scared most people in this county halfto death. The kids used to call him... "Crazy Old Macdonald". They’d sing that old nursery rhyme...

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: (glancing uneasily over her shoulder) He’s not...still around...is he?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: Died about fourteen years ago in a fire. Knocked ...over a kerosene lamp in the barn. Burnt to death

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Jesus.  41.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: What was it about him that...scared people?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: Why don’t you ask Mac? -- It’s his granddaddy. All eyes on MAC.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I don’t remember... A beat --

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: (flippant ) What was he...some kind of axe murderer?

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why don’t you ask him yourself? Beat. Jeremiah’s walked back into the room, his hand bandaged. JEREMIAH (CONT’D) He’s sitting right behind you. --On the mantle. Everyone turns around. A decorative cremation URN is indeed sitting on the mantl Jeremiah picks it up. He holds the urn tenderly in his hands- JEREMIAH (CONT’D) My daddy was a man of vision. People always fear what they don’t understand. Jeremiah looks down at the urn. He’s silent for a moment JEREMIAH (CONT’D) He lived for this land. And he died for it. Rest in peace, daddy. Slowly, Jeremiah lifts the lid off the urn. No one wants to look inside. Finally, Carl leans over, and-- SNEEZES..scattering ashes!  42.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Sorry. An awkward beat. Then Jeremiah laughs, slaps Carl on the back --

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: I’m just yankin’ your chain! It’s an ashtray. --Jethro’s buried right there across the field with the rest of the family. ...Cigar? Jeremiah pulls out a handful of cigars offering them to everyone, as we--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things are...well, dead quiet. Except for an electric BUG ZAPPER. Purple, glowing. We hear a "ZAP" as several bugs meet their maker. We can hear CRICKETS in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: INT -LIVING ROOM -NIGHT -LATER
dialogues.text: Keith, sitting on the COUCH, wearing only his underwear removing his expensive Nikes. Then he lies down, covers himself with a thin farm blanke and tries to get comfortable --

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (muttering to himself) Yeah. Sure. Put the black man on the couch... INT - MAC’S BEDROOM - NIGHT It used to be his grandfather’s room. There are old family photos on the wall. Creepy. Mac stares out the window. Outside, we can see the old

dialogues.speaker: BARN
dialogues.text: in the moonlight. Is that Billy Bob going inside? The bedroom door opens. It’s Jeremiah. Mac turns away, looking back out at the barn.  43.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: That old barn. After the fire...I rebuilt it nail by nail. Just the way your granddaddy would’ve wanted it.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: (not happy) This is his room...isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Was. You ain’t afraid of ghosts, now are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I'll be fine here. Jeremiah holds out a bound stack of envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Thought you might want these. Mac just stares at them. JEREMIAH (CONT’D) Just so you know. After your mother took you away, I wrote you. She returned every one of ‘em. Mac makes no move to take them. Instead, Jeremiah places them on the table. JEREMIAH (CONT’D) Well. Then... I’11 leave you to it. Jeremiah’s about to exit-- JEREMIAH (CONT’D) You got it wrong, boy. I’m not the monster you think.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Maybe you should tell that to the old lady you tried to hit with the shovel.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t pay Jesse no mind at all. She’s just a crazy old woman. Hasn’t been right in the head since her husband passed away. (beat) Wasn’t much right before that, neither.  44.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: She was talking about...a "harvest of blood"... Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Old slave superstition. You sprinkle a little blood mixed with water on the crops, you get yourself a good harvest... So they say.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: "Blood?" Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Chicken blood. -- Anyway..don’t you worry about ol’ Jesse. She won’t be bothering anyone no more.

dialogues.speaker: INT -LIVING ROOM -NIGHT -LATER
dialogues.text: Keith tries to sleep, but doesn’t look comfortable. He looks up at the shadowed wall next to him. Animal heads, stuffed by a taxidermist, stare back at him. He looks at the urn containing cigars. It’s still on the mantle. Jeremiah walks past almost unseen. A little spooked, Keith removes his .38 SPECIAL, checks if it’s loaded--

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s what I’m talkin’ about. He puts it under his pillow. INT. MAC’S BEDROOM -NIGHT MAC’s in a restless sleep on top of the bed. The wind has blown the letters around the room. He wakes suddenly. Disoriented, he runs his hand on the wall above his head, feeling the rough texture of stained wallpaper. From outside there’s the soft strains of tinkling MUSIC...from a child’s music box...barely discernible ove the wind. But eerie...  45. Mac sits up in bed. Looks out the window to --

dialogues.speaker: THE OLD BARN
dialogues.text: That’s where the sound is coming from. As Mac stares... There’s a soft flicker of light from inside the barn...Th flicker grows stronger...are those flames coming out unde the barn doors? KNOCK KNOCK. The flames are gone. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mac? With a jolt, Mac looks to the door. He opens the door, a bit shaken. Suzie stands outside, in sexy nightgown. Just a whisper of satin and chiffon. Very Victoria’s Secret. SUZIE (CONT’D) It’s ten-thirty. I took the clothing option. She gestures at her sheer nightgown. SUZIE (CONT’D) Sort of. She smiles at Mac. He gazes blankly at her -- SUZIE (CONT’D) Well, are you going to invite me in? It’s cold out here! Mac looks at her breasts---

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I can see that. She steps inside. Mac shuts the door. Suzie wastes no time. She locks him in a passionate clinch. They kiss. But Mac’s not responding.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: This...used to be Jethro’s room. The attic.  46.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: When I was a kid...I was never allowed up here... Suzie moves closer--

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: That turns me on even more...forbidden fruit always tastes better. Especially...the cherry. Suzie starts kissing Mac. He’s not responding. SUZIE (CONT’D) What do you want? His permission? No problem. She puts her fingers to her temples, a "mock seance"-- SUZIE (CONT’D) I’m talking to the spirit of Jethro Macdonald. Is it okay to have sex in your old attic with your grandson? We’1l be careful of the bed--

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Let it go.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: I bet if he were still alive, he’d like to watch. She caresses the bedpost-- SUZIE (CONT’D) Think of it ..asa threesome. You. Me. And.. "Jethro."

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I said that’s enough! Mac grabs her roughly, pushing her against the wall. Suzie stares at him like he’s an alien.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Get a life! --and goes out the door, SLAMMING it.  47.

dialogues.speaker: INT -BUS -NIGHT
dialogues.text: Two figures underneath a blanket at the back of the bus. Having sex. It’s Rod & Candy. Then we hear Carl’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Man. That was the weirdest funeral I’ve ever seen. We MOVE to the front of the bus. IAN & CARL are chilling, totally ignoring the Kama Sutra going on in the back. Ian’s swigging from a bottle of Jack Daniels. CARL (CONT’D) He almost brained that old lady with a shovel.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Must be a family feud, dude. You ask me...Mac’s father’s a few bales short of a haystack.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Maybe it runs in the family. Maybe all farmers go crazy after a while. Ian finishes the whiskey, passes the empty bottle to Carl who’s disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I could get used to life on a farm. A cloud of SMOKE blows past Ian. REVEAL ROD & CANDY, post-coital and now standing right behind them, naked and wrapped in a blanket. Rod’s holding a joint.

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: Me too. He grins, passing it to Ian and Carl-- Ian glances out the bus window. Did he just see a figure pass by?

dialogues.speaker: INT -BARN -NIGHT
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON the row of hanging FARM IMPLEMENTS, inside the barn. A gloved HAND reaches out -- and selects the SCYTHE, pull  48. it off its hook. We get the feeling it’s not going to be used ....for harvesting corn tonight.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A modest FARM HOUSE in the vicinity of the Macdonald farm It belongs to JESSE, the old woman we saw at the funeral. Jesse’s outside, standing by a bonfire, engaged in a Paga ritual of protection. She throws a STRAW DOLL into the fire. The flames quickly turn it to ash. She sprinkles some sort of SPICE on the fire. It FLARES up wildly, with the force of a photographic flash. And as it does -- A FIGURE is suddenly visible...standing on the other side of the bonfire. The intruder wears a grotesque burlap -stitched mask over its head. Dressed in farmer’s overalls...and boots that we’ve seen before. --a hellish human SCARECROW. -- And in its hand....the long curved blade of a SCYTHE. The blade of the Reaper. JESSE ..starts backing away, her eyes fixed tight on the SCARECROW, a look of fear and possibly recognition on her face-- --And she turns and runs. Into the house--

dialogues.speaker: INT SMALL FARMHOUSE, (LIVING ROOM)
dialogues.text: Breathing sharply, JESSE SLAMS the FRONT DOOR, locking it and leaning against it. Safe only for a moment, becaus CRASH -- the blade of the SCYTHE rips through the wood..inches from her face. JESSE screams. She runs towards the KITCHEN, as the SOUND of splintering wood rings out and--

dialogues.speaker: INT -KITCHEN
dialogues.text: JESSE frantically searches drawers for a weapon. A knife?  49.

dialogues.speaker: INT -LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: THE front WINDOW PANE breaks open -- A hand reaches in to open the latch. Jesse runs -- the SCARECROW is now inside On the walls of the house: Straw dolls, symbols and other hand-made articles of protection. The SCARECROW slices at them with the scythe, cutting them to shreds. Then the Scarecrow stops. Listening...trying to determine where its prey has gone.

dialogues.speaker: EXT -BACK OF FARMHOUSE -NIGHT
dialogues.text: The SCARECROW comes out the back door. Moonlight. Except for the crickets...and soft clucking of chickens, it’s quiet. The Scarecrow looks around. Where did she go?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: It’s a long structure with hundreds upon hundreds of chickens - a real chicken nightmare. JESSE crouches inside the structure, terrified, trying not to make a sound. Through the small SLATS, we can see SCARECROW walking slowly past.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BACK OF FARMHOUSE -CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: The SCARECROW pauses, then starts to head away towards th cornfield. She’s fooled him!

dialogues.speaker: INT -CHICKEN HOUSE
dialogues.text: JESSE relaxes ever so slightly, as the SCARECROW moves aw HER FOOT..touches one of the chickens! It starts clucking

dialogues.speaker: EXT -BACK OF FARMHOUSE
dialogues.text: The SCARECROW....whips its head around, hearing--

dialogues.speaker: INT -CHICKEN HOUSE
dialogues.text: JESSE cringes, praying she’s still safe. CRASH! The SCARECROW’s inside --  50. The CHICKENS freak, going crazy, flapping their wings-- The SCARECROW’S boots trample on EGGS, smashing them. A chaos of chickens and feathers, trampled eggs and crazy pecking. Still crouching, JESSE desperately raises her hands to wa off the blade -- She screams -- The blade, sticky through the mist of chicken blood and feathers, slices the air in a shiny arc -- And comes to rest with a sickening thump in Jesse’s chest As her blood drains out --The blade swings again, and again --

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The red and orange flare of the rising sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy in Rod’s arms. In the front, Ian & Carl. All asleep.

dialogues.speaker: COCK A DOODLE DO
dialogues.text: -- a ROOSTER crows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KEITH wakes up, opens one eye, hung-over, not happy about the rooster.

dialogues.speaker: INT -FARM HOUSE PASSAGE- LATER
dialogues.text: SUZIE, now dressed, walks down the passage. The ROOSTER crows again, as Suzie walks into--

dialogues.speaker: INT -LIVING ROOM -CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: KEITH is up, hung-over and standing in his underwear aiming his .38 Special through the window. Suzie groans.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: It’s a farm, Keith. You’re not supposed to shoot the rooster.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: He started it.  51.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: You seen Mac? His bed hasn’t been slept in.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (beat) What?! You mean ..I slept on this couch for nothing?!

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: A figure sprawled on a bed of hay. Head to the side, legs and arms akimbo. No sign of movement. It’s MAC. The barn door swings open. Sunlight floods in. Suzie’s found him, Still angry from the night before, she kicks his boot.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Hey -- No reaction. She bends over, shakes him--

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mac! A groan from the floor. Mac raises his head, instinctivel shields his eyes against the light -- SUZIE (CONT’D) We’re almost ready. what the hell are you doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I ...heard something...came in here last night. Must have gone to sleep. He clutches his head in agony. Slowly, he sits up, brushing some hay from his clothes. His hand is cut.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: How’d you get that? Playing with your pitchfork?

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Picked up one of those shears. Blade’s razor sharp. --Where is everyone?

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Getting ready.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Look. You want to talk about this?  52.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. Keith’s about to use the rooster for target practice. Besides...you didn’t seem too interested last night. Mac pulls her down on top of him --

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Strange...I can feel my old self coming back...

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Mmmm - so can lI... A-HEM. Someone clears their throat. Mac and Suzie look up to see Jeremiah standing in the doorway. Frustrated, Suzie gets up. SUZIE (CONT’D) Morning Jeremiah. But Jeremiah keeps his eyes leveled on Mac.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Mornin’. A beat. Suzie turns and looks at Mac --

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Better get a move on. Or I won’t be able to guarantee the safety of the old Macdonald cock much longer. Jeremiah raises an eyebrow, as Suzie exits.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Women. Can’t live with ‘em...can’t shoot ‘em. ..Without good reason. Mac half-smiles. The SCYTHE is back where it was. A smear of blood on the blade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremiah sits in an old wooden chair on the porch, whittl a small piece of wood with a pocket KNIFE. The BAND MEMBERS are getting ready to leave, getting on the bus.  53. KEITH is fastening the dirtbike to the back of the bus.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: Sure gonna miss you boys. ..Need a hand with that? Billy Bob grins, spits tobacco a little too near Keith’s Nikes. Over near the HOUSE, MAC walks up to Jeremiah, who’s whittling a piece of wood. Mac pauses, trying to figure out how to say goodbye. Jeremiah glances at the cut on Mac’s hand. Then-

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: You’1l be back.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. He holds out his hand to Mac. Reluctantly, Mac reaches out to shake it. Jeremiah squeezes. A drop of Mac’s blood falls into the dust.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: You’re a Macdonald. It’s in your blood.

dialogues.speaker: THE BAND MEMBERS
dialogues.text: ...take their seats. Candy is already sitting by herself, turning over a deck Tarot Cards. As Suzie moves past her--

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: (dryly) . Let me guess. We’re going on a "long trip".

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: (turning over a card) Not according to these. Mac enters the bus, sits down by Suzie. She notices his hand, bleeding slightly.  54. Carl starts the bus. KEITH couldn’t be happier.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Hallelujah! ...Civilization...here I come!

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Through the windows of the bus, receding into the distance. Jeremiah just stares. Billy Bob waves and grins. In response, looking through the window, KEITH gives him the finger. Billy Bob smiles, and gives him the finger back. MAC, alone in his seat, glances down at the cut on his ha

dialogues.speaker: EXT -COUNTRY ROAD -MORNING -MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Churning up dust, the BUS thunders down the bumpy country road, a few miles from the farmhouse. Rock music blaring. Suddenly, there’s a horrible grinding sound. The bus SWER - and the engine CUTS out. The bus comes to rest ina thick cloud of dirt.

dialogues.speaker: INT -BUS
dialogues.text: CARL, at the steering wheel, tries to restart it. No dice. Just a dead clicking sound.

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: Is it supposed to do that? The others glare at her.

dialogues.speaker: EXT -COUNTRY ROAD
dialogues.text: The broken-down BUS on the side of the road, with its HOO up. Sitting in the dirt, hot and bothered, the BAND are lounging around, waiting for Carl to return with help. Then, in the distance, almost like a mirage -- A TRACTOR, slowly making its way towards them.  55.

dialogues.speaker: EXT -COUNTRY ROAD
dialogues.text: The TRACTOR pulls to a halt. CARL is sitting on the back. And in the driver’s seat, with a grin on his face...Billy Bob enjoying the moment.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: (especially to Keith) Long time...no see.

dialogues.speaker: EXT -MACDONALD FARM -LATER
dialogues.text: The BUS has been towed back to the farm. Suzie and Carl a looking under the hood. The others are gathered around.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Looks like the alternator.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s the alternator all right.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: How would you know? You’re looking at my tits. (Beat ) Jesus, Carl. Your job is to keep us on the road!

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I didn’t do anything---

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s just the problem.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Tell me you checked the bus before we left, Carl. BILLY BOB has come out of the house, walks over to them--

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: Just talked to Orwell down at the garage. Says getting a new alternator for your bus is no problem.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: (pumps his fist) Alright!

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: Could take a little while, though.  56.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What’s a "little while?"

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: Two.. maybe three days. Everyone groans.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What?!! I can’t fuckin’ believe this!! You mean we’re stuck in Redneck River Valley without a ride? (to Jeremiah) No offense.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: None taken. The Lord works in mysterious ways. Mac locks eyes with Jeremiah.

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: (whining) Rod....I have to get back to my job.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Someone actually ...employs you?

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: I happen to be a professional.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Which street corner? They’re about to go at it again --

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: (grins) She’s a Tarot Card Reader at a shopping mall.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: What a surprise. --What about our audition?

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: If you’re looking to practice...why don’t you set up over there..... in the barn? While the others appraise the barn..Mac stares at Jeremia  57.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: IAN wanders up to KEITH, a bottle in hand. KEITH is standing with his .38 in his hand in a firing stance. MAC’s watchi Irritated with the band’s time wasting.

dialogues.speaker: BLAM
dialogues.text: As KEITH pulls the trigger, we see -- Several TIN CANS, placed on a FENCE as targets. A TIN CAN goes flying. Keith shoots again. Suzie walks up behind Keith.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Having fun, Keith? BLAM! KEITH misses again.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Damn! You made me miss!

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: Leaning against a post nearby, watching. He spits tobacco into the dust.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: Want me to move ‘em a little closer for ya? KEITH turns around --

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You think you can do better "Billy Bob"?? Billy Bob grins. Walks over to Keith, who puts the gun in his hand. Billy Bob "hefts" it for a second -- and then in one deft, effortless MOTION --

dialogues.speaker: BANG
dialogues.text: Three cans are blasted off the fence post. Billy Bob grins, pleased with himself. He hands the gun back to Keith.  58.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: -- Not bad. Prefer a shotgun myself. Comes in much more handy on a farm. (pause) ‘Course, your kind wouldn’t know too much about that. Keith bristles.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: My kind? You mean -- black people? Billy Bob grins at him, spits.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: Musicians.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: CARL, the roadie, is unloading the band’s equipment off the BUS, staggering under the weight. The others are helping, move stuff to the barn. Candy picks up a single microphone to carry. Jeremiah approaches Mac.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: ..As long as you’re stayin’...mind giving me a hand? Jeremiah nods to a TRACTOR nearby.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: Carl! Mac motions to Carl to help Jeremiah--

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: (to Mac) Actually, I was talkin’ about you. A moment as Mac looks at his father, then looks at the ba Mac pauses, trying to decide. JEREMIAH (CONT’D) May as well. They’re having a good time shooting tin cans.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FARM -MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: MAC’s now reluctantly sitting next to Jeremiah on the TRACTOR. As they head off toward the fields--  59. MAC’s POV FROM THE MOVING TRACTOR --passing by the band members, deserting them. Keith exchanges a "how could he do this?" look with Suzie Mac turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEREMIAH and MAC are hard at work -- trying to remove a tree branch that’s poked through the fence. The tractor’s park nearby.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMIAH
dialogues.text: Feel’s good, doesn’t it. (pause) Land. A man’s born on it. A man’s buried on it. In between you just got to do what you can to make a living. It ain’t easy... Mac has his shirt off, sweating in the sun. He reaches down to the pile of tools nearby, picks up a sharp AXE, about to swing it. Jeremiah grabs the axe handle suddenly. JEREMIAH (CONT’D) Not that. Mac glances at the handle. "Jethro Macdonald" is burned into the handle. Jeremiah takes out another axe. -- JEREMIAH (CONT’D) Try this one... Mac takes it, and with a sure hand, chops off the branch. Jeremiah watches proudly. Even Mac seems a little pleased with himself. JEREMIAH (CONT’D) Just what I said this farm needs. A little new blood.  60.

dialogues.speaker: EXT -BACK OF FARMHOUSE -AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: It’s getting late. Mac hasn’t returned yet. Keith comes out and the others come out of the barn.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Guess Mac’s still off on the "hayride". Pissed-off, Keith spies the lone SCARECROW in the field. He takes careful aim--

dialogues.speaker: BLAM
dialogues.text: THE SCARECROW is hit, slumps over on its post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally returning from the field, Jeremiah stops the trac by the barn. Mac looks at Jeremiah, the beginning of a strange bond forming between them. Mac pushes open the barn door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band’s equipment is all set up. But the band are nowhere to be seen. Mac’s missed the practice. Leaving Mac alone, Jeremiah drives the tractor toward the back of the house--

dialogues.speaker: A SCARECROW
dialogues.text: ...Starting to stand up in the sun. We PULL BACK,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEREMIAH is in the cornfield, FIXING the Scarecrow that Keith shot. He hoists it up, affixing to a pole. He looks over his shoulder, hearing, LOUD ROCK MUSIC, coming from...THE BARN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAND....are attempting to play an upbeat rock number. Billy Bob and Candy are their "audience". Mac is playing rhythm guitar, but he seems to have something else on his mind. Suzie looks across at him, perturbed. Then something else distracts her. She holds up her hand, stops the music --  61.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Hold it, hold it. Aren’t you forgetting something, Rod?

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Like your guitar break.

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: It’s coming right up. After the third verse.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: Second verse!

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: Jeez, what’s the difference? Just ‘cause it’s rock ‘n roll, doesn’t mean it’s be set in stone. Suzie looks at Mac. He looks pale.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: You wanna know the difference? The difference is that you’re screwing up the song.

dialogues.speaker: ROD
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure. I’m screwing up the song. You’re the one who’s been two beats behind since we kicked it off. Mac isn’t paying attention. MAC’S ...Sweating, staring transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: What the fuck you talking about, man?

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: He’s right. You were behind. But Suzie’s distracted, watching Mac carefully. Max plugs his lead into one of the mixing consoles. Blood gushes down the perspex channels...  62.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Bullshit! Next thing you’11 be telling me, black man don’t have rhythm! --and then, as Mac watches, the BLOOD is gone...just as quickly as it appeared. KEITH (CONT’D) Yo. "Billy Bob". Was I two beats behind, or what?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Nope.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: See?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: You were a beat and a quarter behind.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Fuck you! If you’re such an expert on music, why don’t you go get your dueling banjo and sit in on the next song?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY BOB
dialogues.text: I ain’t never played a banjo in my life. Billy Bob stands over Keith’s electric organ..plays a burst of Toccata and Fugue with flawless grace and precision. He stops, grinning widely at Keith-- BILLY BOB (CONT’D) ...but I do play some organ in church on Sundays. Mac looks at the cut on his hand. It looks worse. He takes his guitar off. It hits the ground with a SQUELCH of FEEDBACK.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: (sour) You guys figure it out. I’m taking a break.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Yeah. Good idea. Go milk the cows, feed the chickens.  63. Mac walks out, slamming the barn door. Keith looks at everyone innocently, especially Suzie. KEITH (CONT’D) .. What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac examines the small carved figure he received from Bil Bob at the club. It’s slightly burnt, with the stem snapped off. He picks at the stem with a small penknife and looks around and picks up a piece of wood which he examines and starts to whittle. Suzie walks up to find Mac. She watches him whittling a small piece of wood, trying to fit a stem onto the figure

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: You wanna tell me what’s going on? Mac looks up. He’s preoccupied with the stem and the damaged figure.

dialogues.speaker: MAC
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: SUZIE
dialogues.text: You never had trouble communicating before. Mac pauses in his whittling. Then goes back to it. Suzie loses it. She grabs the knife and wood from his han SUZIE (CONT’D) What’s wrong with you? Look, if you want to bail on me, that’s fine. But not the band. She throws the stem and the figure on the ground. SUZIE (CONT’D) Keith’s right. The sooner we get off this farm...the better. Mac watches her. He picks up the figure.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM -LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: ON KEITH’S GUN --resting on a table. KEITH, in his socks, is taking a nap on the couch. Suddenly, we hear a loud MOOoOOOO000, from a cow.  64. Keith wakes up -- and glances at the floor. Something’s missing. His expensive Nikes are gone. He gets down on his hands and knees, feeling around under the couch. Nope. No Nikes.

dialogues.speaker: KEITH
dialogues.text: Shit! ! Keith grabs his gun, heading out---

dialogues.speaker: EXT -FARM- LATE AFTERNOON
